title: Does the particle of light travel through time? - Quora

response.answer_text: The fundamental light particle, better known as the photon is a carrier of information across space-time symmetry. Think of a paper boat traveling down a stream, collecting an endless series of snapshots of its surroundings. Now imagine that this stream is going down a mountain. At the bottom of which a person waits to collect those images. Now the real question that will boil a triple PhD’s brain is “Will you be able to determine the elevation of those images from the bottom of the mountain?” The answer is no, you will not. This is a perfect explanation of space-time symmetry in regard to observation, using the z-axis as a reference to time passage rates. If a traveller travels from a planet A to another planet B (A being the earth and B being distance d apart and stationary relative to earth) with a velocity v, the time, as measured by an observer stationary with respect to the earth ( call it ‘earth time’ or ET) will be d/v. But the wristwatch time ( called thr Proper Time) of the traveller will be less by a factor (square root of {1—v exp2/ c exp 2). Let us call this ratio r. Then the Proper Time (TT) of the traveller is vr. ET>TT From the point of you of the traveller, ET runs slower and vice versa. Both earth time and traveller’s time run normally with respect to earthbound observer and the traveller respectively. But when they look at each other’s clock, they both appear dilated by a factor r. If v comes closer and closer to c, r will become smaller and smaller and the TT (of the traveller) as observed by earthbound observer will be smaller and smaller as compared to ET (which will appear to run normally for an earthbound observer.) Similarly, for the traveller, the TT will continue to tick at normal speed. When v=c (which is impossible, but suppose that for the sake of argument), r =0 and so is TT. The time of travel from A to B as measured on the earth is d/c, but as measured by the traveller (the photon), it is 0. Thus, from the perspective of the photon, all distances in the infinite universe are covered in 0 time. But there is no reason to suppose that photon’s own wristwatch stops. The clock showing Proper Time must keep running at the normal speed. For the photon, the entire universe is covered in 0 time, but what happens in the next instant, no one can say. Where is the photon ( in its own perspective) after it has covered the entire universe instantaneously? Surely not in the same universe. Does it make sense? But neither does the thought of an observer travelling with velocity of light!

No, light does not travel through time only its clocks ticks down much slower and time delays for it with respect to the observer but for the light particles which are photons time remains constant, and nothing travels time at high speed only its time slows down for the observer , but for the thing which is travelling time remains constant.
